text.p: Lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their Wednesday editions. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- The ruling Homeland Union party goes to the local elections with basketball players. The head coach of the national basketball team Vladas Garastas and Atlanta Olympics prize winner Tomas Pacesas were included in the candidate list of the Homeland Union.
- The Vilnius prosecutor's office finished the investigation of the biggest petroleum smuggling case involving 11 million litas of petroleum. Four out of six suspects are customs officials.
- The healh care minister intends to promote the local production of pharmaceuticals.
- Hungarian President Arpad Goncz, who arrived in Vilnius on an official visit, promised that his country will co-operate with Lithuania in seeking membership of EU and NATO.
- The newspaper publishes an interview with the sentenced leader of Kaunas criminal world, Henrikas Daktaras, who denies his guilt.
- Italy is ready to start negotiations concerning a visa-free regime and re-admission agreements between the two countries.
- The newspaper publishes an interview with Darius Ereminas who underwent kidney transplant surgery four months ago about the problems he had to overcome after the operation.

- Lithuanian President Algirdas Brazauskas signed a law which will allow the government to pass the control of the planned Butinge oil terminal to private local and foreign investors. According to the law, the state's stake in the terminal will be 34 percent.
- After decentralising the heating energy sector it is expected that prices will rise 30 percent, a decrease in consumers and a flourishing small energy production sector.

- 50 percent of Lithuania's population would vote for membership in the EU and 11 percent against, Baltic Surveys people opinion poll shows. The number of Eurosceptics has increased by 5 percent since 1995.
